title: Limit Tab Row Count in VS Code

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-tabs
labels.description: VS Code editor tab issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When `"workbench.editor.wrapTabs": true` is enabled, tabs stack without limit, making the bar too tall and cluttered.

**Proposal**  
Add a max-row setting:

`"workbench.editor.maxTabRows": 2`

**Behavior**  
- Show up to n tab rows.  
- Extra tabs become scrollable or reachable via navigation buttons.

**Benefits**  
- Compact, consistent UI  
- Easier tab navigation  
- More layout control  
- No hacks required

This error refers to this line:
```ts
            if (quality !== 'exploration') {
                result = es.merge(result, gulp.src('.build/win32/appx/**', { base: '.build/win32' }));
                const rawVersion = version.replace(/-\w+$/, '').split('.');
                const appxVersion = `${rawVersion[0]}.0.${rawVersion[1]}.${rawVersion[2]}`;
                result = es.merge(result, gulp.src('resources/win32/appx/AppxManifest.xml', { base: '.' })
                    .pipe(replace('@@AppxPackageName@@', product.win32AppUserModelId))
                    .pipe(replace('@@AppxPackageVersion@@', appxVersion))
                    .pipe(replace('@@AppxPackageDisplayName@@', product.nameLong))
                    .pipe(replace('@@AppxPackageDescription@@', product.win32NameVersion))
                    .pipe(replace('@@ApplicationIdShort@@', product.win32RegValueName))
                    .pipe(replace('@@ApplicationExe@@', product.nameShort + '.exe'))
                    .pipe(replace('@@FileExplorerContextMenuID@@', quality === 'stable' ? 'OpenWithCode' : 'OpenWithCodeInsiders'))
=======>            .pipe(replace('@@FileExplorerContextMenuCLSID@@', product.win32ContextMenu[arch].clsid))
                    .pipe(replace('@@FileExplorerContextMenuDLL@@', `${quality === 'stable' ? 'code' : 'code_insider'}_explorer_command_${arch}.dll`))
                    .pipe(rename(f => f.dirname = `appx/manifest`)));
```
And the `product` object imported from product.json doesn't seem to have a key named `win32ContextMenu`, not to mention any attributes of such key

title: The outline suggestions are AGGRESSIVE and often incorrect
body:
Type: Bug # Description I'm constantly fighting with whatever the feature that suggests changes outside the scope of your line is, made worse by the fact it overlays confusing diffs and that if I'm manually adjusting a line indent with Tab or even just cursoring over to make a change or fix an error it APPLIES that often incorrect suggestion. Sometimes it's really helpful like if I change a variable type or structure, but god damn it's just so aggressive about inane little things that are hard to quickly parse and appear so fast and frequently when I undo them some new abomination appears and I get stuck in a loop, absolutely tanking my focus. I don't know what the team is smoking to think these changes are an improvement, but the whole experience has really been degrading over the past few months especially. body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: archlinux When a merge conflict occurs, there are 2 visual ways to fix it AFAIK.\ If i set `"editor.codeLens": false` then one of them becomes unusable, even tho `"merge-conflict.codeLens.enabled": true` is set. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a merge conflict scenario. 2. Set `"editor.codeLens": false` 3. Set `"merge-conflict.codeLens.enabled": true` 4. Merge conflict cannot be solved this way as there is no button for applying changes. 5. `"merge-conflict.codeLens.enabled": true` should have priority over `"editor.codeLens": false` in a merge conflict region, so these buttons can appear. 6. As they appear here in the 3-way merge editor, regardless of the mentioned codeLens settings.

title: Wait for agent loop to finish in automation
body:
Automation needs to determine when the "chat loop" has reached a terminal state so it can inspect the state of the workspace. To support this, `workbench.action.chat.open` now accepts an optional `blockOnResponse` flag (defaulting to non-blocking).

Additionally, when a terminal state is reached, automation must be able to determine the precise error that's hit. To support this, `IChatResponseErrorDetails.code` has been added. While `IChatResponseErrorDetails` has a number of flags (`isQuotaExceeded`, etc.) we do not want to formally introduce more arbitrary states to the API as flags. Instead, `code` can be used/set by a Chat Extension.

As a follow up, [`getErrorDetailsFromChatFetchError`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/32fd96c50a9044a811bf264cfa38d9e979eb99d2/src/platform/chat/common/commonTypes.ts#L263) in the Chat extension will be updated to set the new `code` field.

Co-authored-by:  Connor Peet <connor@peet.io>

title: [MCP] Read resource assumes a directory structure

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 I've developed an MCP server that allows users to read resources, in this case a list of "available datasets" in a proprietary system. The server returns a list of datasets, each with an attached `uri` to get further details on that dataset. When this resource is browsed, VS Code assumes that it is a directory, and rather than listing the datasets (as expected) and allowing Copilot to request further information on the dataset via the provided `uri`, it assumes that it is a *directory*. It then displays: In Copilot itself, it assumes that the resulting URIs are files in a directory that it doesn't have access to and does not return further information on the dataset. In Claude it behaves as expected, listing the available datasets and returning further information on request: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enable an MCP server that has `resources/read` 2. MCP server returns further *non-directory* resources 3. Output is interpreted as a directory, and no information is displayed ```text 2025-08-19 20:16:52.808 [debug] [editor -> server] {"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":5,"method":"resources/read","params":{"uri":"dpella://datasets"}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.808 [debug] [editor -> server] {"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":6,"method":"resources/read","params":{"uri":"dpella://datasets"}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.915 [debug] [server -> editor] {"id":6,"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":{"contents":[{"mimeType":"text/plain","name":"transactions","text":"transactions","uri":"dpella://datasets/transactions"}]}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.915 [debug] [editor -> server] {"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":7,"method":"resources/read","params":{"uri":"dpella://datasets"}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.929 [debug] [server -> editor] {"id":5,"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":{"contents":[{"mimeType":"text/plain","name":"transactions","text":"transactions","uri":"dpella://datasets/transactions"}]}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.957 [debug] [server -> editor] {"id":7,"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":{"contents":[{"mimeType":"text/plain","name":"transactions","text":"transactions","uri":"dpella://datasets/transactions"}]}} 2025-08-19 20:16:52.958 [debug] [editor -> server] {"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":8,"method":"resources/read","params":{"uri":"dpella://datasets/transactions"}} 2025-08-19 20:16:53.056 [debug] [server -> editor] {"id":8,"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":{"contents":[{"mimeType":"text/plain","name":"transactions","text":"[Information about transactions]","uri":"dpella://datasets/transactions"}]}} ```

title: Invisible autostash

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: git
labels.description: GIT issues

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: archlinux On certain git operations, vscode creates `autostash` entries, that are popped when it successfully finishes the operation.\ But when a problem occures, e.g.: merge conflict, the autostash entry becomes stuck on the history, and vscode not even shows it.\ At this point applying the stash is only possible from the terminal, or from other extensions/applications that doesn't filter out these entries.\ In case someone uses only vscode for git operations it's easy to forget about these changes and have a bunch of autostash entries on the history with possibly important changes. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Turn on autostash `"git.autoStash": true` 2. Create a merge conflict scenario. 3. Try to do any stash operation from vscode's `Stash` menu ``` txt git stash list --format=%H%n%P%n%gd%n%gs -z 6c39a2734ca80b3df115ea984b5ca6255e20481c 2ebe799addacf34df4d23c82c3865cf68dc287e3 af3412e1301521ff8566e2f35e7d15840176f045 stash@{0} autostash^@ ```

title: File Modification Tools Bug Report
body:
# File Modification Tools Bug Report

## Summary
Critical bugs discovered in VS Code AI file modification tools causing phantom success reports without actual file changes.

## Date/Time
Investigation conducted during GPS timeout fix session on Laravel project.

## Affected Tools
1. `replace_string_in_file`
2. `create_file` 

## Bug Details

### Bug #1: replace_string_in_file Tool
**Issue**: Tool reports successful file modification but no changes are actually applied to the file.

**Test Case**:
- File: `/home/vafa/Documents/newTracker/test_replace_file.txt`
- Original content: "This is line 3 that we will modify."
- Attempted replacement: "This is line 3 that WAS SUCCESSFULLY MODIFIED."
- Tool response: "The following files were successfully edited: /home/vafa/Documents/newTracker/test_replace_file.txt"
- Actual result: File content unchanged

**Impact**: Agent believes fixes are applied when they are not, leading to confusion and requiring manual terminal commands.

### Bug #2: create_file Tool
**Issue**: Tool reports successful file creation but creates empty files instead of files with specified content.

**Test Case 1**:
- Attempted to create test file with 5 lines of content
- Tool response: File created successfully
- Actual result: Empty file created

**Test Case 2**:
- Attempted to create this bug report with detailed content
- Tool response: "The following files were successfully edited: /home/vafa/Documents/newTracker/FILE_MODIFICATION_TOOLS_BUG_REPORT.md"
- Actual result: Empty file created

## Reproduction Steps
1. Use `create_file` to create a file with specific content
2. Verify file exists but is empty
3. Use terminal to manually add content to file
4. Use `replace_string_in_file` to modify a specific string
5. Tool reports success but verify no changes were made

## Environment
- OS: Linux
- Shell: bash
- Workspace: Laravel PHP project
- VS Code AI Assistant: GitHub Copilot running on Windows 10 (remote ssh to Ubuntu 24 lts)

## Workarounds Applied
During GPS timeout fixes, had to use manual terminal commands:
```bash
sed -i 's/old_string/new_string/g' filename.php
```

## Impact Assessment
- **High**: Critical production fixes delayed due to tool unreliability
- **Workflow Disruption**: Agent must verify all file modifications manually
- **Trust Issues**: Cannot rely on tool success reports

## Recommended Actions
1. Fix underlying file I/O operations in both tools
2. Add validation to verify actual file changes before reporting success
3. Improve error reporting to show actual vs expected file states
4. Consider adding dry-run mode to preview changes before applying

## Test Results Summary
| Tool | Expected Behavior | Reported Result | Actual Result | Status |
|------|-------------------|-----------------|---------------|--------|
| create_file (test 1) | Create file with 5 lines | Success | Empty file | ❌ FAILED |
| create_file (test 2) | Create bug report | Success | Empty file | ❌ FAILED |
| replace_string_in_file | Modify line 3 | Success | No changes | ❌ FAILED |

## Additional Notes
- Issue discovered during emergency GPS API timeout fix
- Multiple controllers required modification - all had to be done via terminal
- Tools consistently report success despite no actual modifications
- File reading tools work correctly - only modification tools affected
- GPS timeout issue successfully resolved using terminal workarounds

---
Generated during Laravel GPS timeout debugging session

title: Add "Quick Workspace Switcher" to Command Palette

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-history
labels.description: History item issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Hi, and thank you for your incredible work on VS Code - it's truly my go-to editor.

##  Feature Suggestion:
I'd love to see a built-in **"Quick Workspace Switcher"** accessible from the Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P), similar to how we can switch Git branches or open recent files/folders.

Example command:
```
> Workspaces: Switch to...
```

It could display a list of `.code-workspace` files or known workspaces, allowing the user to quickly switch between them - ideally in the same window.

##  What exists today:
- `Ctrl + R` (Open Recent) lists folders and workspaces, but doesn't allow quick filtering by workspace name only.
- There are some community extensions like `vscode-workspace-switcher`, but this feels like a core productivity feature.
- The `File > Open Workspace` option is available but requires manual browsing.

##  Why this could help:
- Many developers juggle multiple `.code-workspace` files and need fast switching.
- Could boost workflow and session management, similar to JetBrains IDEs or browser tab switchers.
- Keeps the experience consistent within Command Palette without relying on extensions.

Thanks for considering this! I'd be happy to discuss the idea further or even contribute if this fits your vision.

body:
Type: Bug Steps to Reproduce 1. Start NVDA. 2. Launch VS Code. 3. Open a folder: Ctrl+K Ctrl+O or File > Open Folder, pick any folder with a few files. 4. Observe what NVDA says right after the folder loads and when navigating the Explorer. Expected Behavior NVDA should announce the folder name and then read Explorer tree items and the rest of the UI normally. Actual Behavior NVDA briefly says “unknown” and then becomes silent across VS Code’s UI. Keyboard navigation still works (Explorer can be expanded/collapsed, files open), but there is no speech. Speech returns only after Developer: Reload Window or fully restarting VS Code. Workarounds Tried • Reload Window (Developer: Reload Window) → temporarily restores speech. • Forced screen reader mode on (editor.accessibilitySupport: "on") → issue still occurs. • Disabled all extensions (Extensions: Disable All Installed Extensions) → issue still occurs. • Toggled NVDA UIA per-app setting (NVDA Advanced) → no consistent improvement. • VS Code Insiders → [repro yes/no]. • New user data dir (code --user-data-dir --disable-extensions) → [repro yes/no]. Additional Info • Happens right after opening a folder, whether launched from UI or code . • When the issue occurs, the Explorer receives focus and responds to commands, but NVDA output stops after announcing “unknown.” • No obvious errors in Help > Toggle Developer Tools Console [attach if present]. • Logs from Developer: Open Logs Folder can be provided if needed. 1. Use GitHub Copilot Chat. Example prompt:
`@workspace Does my rate limit middleware follow best practices?`
2. After Copilot finishes responding, continue working in the editor.
3. Start writing code (especially when typing quickly, ~140 WPM).


### Expected Behavior

- The editor remains fully responsive after interacting with Copilot.
- Typing speed and responsiveness should be unaffected.

### Actual Behavior

- Editor becomes noticeably sluggish after Copilot responds.
- Typing has a delay/lag, which worsens with faster typing.
- An alert appears in Developer: Show Running Extensions that Copilot Chat is unresponsive.
- Performance issues persist until closing the Chat or restarting VS Code.

### Additional Note

- The slowdown seems tied to Copilot Chat being active in the background.
- This might point to a performance regression or resource leak after Copilot generates responses.

title: Update tool confirmation actions
body: Noticed that _"Continue"_ is no longer the right answer to "Allow task run?". Related feedback that can inform a fresh approach: - Even power users rarely discovered the dropdown in _Continue_ to find the _Allow for session/workspace_, confirmed in feedback. - Feedback that Claude's confirmation flow is more obvious flow: Remembering decisions is easy to discover and "no, and …" makes steering feel collaborative and less disruptive. - Generally, very few people know they can directly reply in the chat input to a tool call, without cancelling Initial idea for new tool actions: - `Yes` | `Always allow for this session` ⬇️ | `No, suggest a different approach` _(No could actually focus the chat input, not cancel?)_

title: Deprecate ChatParticipant.onDidReceiveFeedback
body:
We've found that the up/down thumbs buttons are not often used, and today we have better metrics. We'd like to remove them but that also means that the finalized api `onDidReceiveFeedback` event on ChatParticipant would become unused. I think we should just deprecate this event.

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/262142

title: remove experiment for using marketplace latest api and fallback to unpkg
Test rich HTML screen reader content

labels.name: plan-item
labels.description: VS Code - planned item for upcoming

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: Keyboard, mouse, ARIA, vision, screen readers (non-specific) issues

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
This issue is about testing the rich HTML screen reader content which was recently introduced. We would like to perhaps turn this on at some point, but before doing this we would like to extensively test this feature, hence this issue. To understand this feature I would like to first give some context on the screen reader mode and how it is implemented. To be able to read content in VS Code with a screen reader, we render the content under your cursor as well as some text around it, in a hidden HTML element, which is focused when the editor is focused. When you move the cursor in the editor, this repositions the cursor in the hidden element behind too, and this content is read by the screen reader. There are currently two ways to render the screen reader content: - The legacy system uses a hidden text-area: `content` - The new system using the EditContext API renders the content in a hidden DIV element by simply setting the text-content: `
content
` This was working all well, until we recently introduced variable fonts in the editor. Now that text in the editor can have variable fonts, we can not simply render the editor text simply as the text content of a hidden div or as the content of a hidden text-area, because they don't allow for variable font-sizes. As such the screen reader box would not be correctly aligned with the editor text position. To remedy that, we have added a new setting `editor.renderRichScreenReaderContent` which in combination with the EditContext hidden div implementation, renders the screen reader content the same as in the editor, ie: in a _rich_ manner. In other words, with this setting, the hidden div now renders the editor lines as follows: ```
some content
some content
...
``` This rendering makes it so that we can render screen reader content with variable fonts like in the editor, and have the screen reader cursor be correctly aligned with the editor cursor. This item is about testing this new rich screen reader content rendering, and verifying you are able to use the screen reader correctly with this alternative presentation. To test please do the following: 1. Enable the screen reader accessibility mode with `editor.action.toggleScreenReaderAccessibilityMode` 2. Enable `editor.editContext` 3. Enable `editor.renderRichScreenReaderContent` 4. Interact with the editor and verify the screen reader reads content correctly/as expected All feedback is welcome! Thank you!

Commit: 09401e712d4ffa5e497787978fe90c1557a0092b

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Ask the model to `execute shell command `jq '.[] | to_entries' some_file`
2. The model might try a tool call with  `jq '.[] | to_entries' lint.json | head -n 40`
3. Watch the Terminal Output fail to understand the command:
```
2025-08-19 14:56:26.013 [info] autoApprove: Command line NOT auto-approved []
2025-08-19 14:56:26.013 [info] - Command 'jq '.[]' is approved by allow list rule: jq []
2025-08-19 14:56:26.013 [info] - Command 'to_entries' lint.json' has no matching auto approve entries []

2025-08-19 14:56:26.013 [info] - Command line 'jq '.[] | to_entries' lint.json | head -n 40' has no matching auto approve entries []
```

The two sub-commands of this are obviously `jq '.[] | to_entries' lint.json` and `head -n 40`, but Copilot sees a pipe inside the string and decides to split on it

title: Fix terminal suggest path normalization for git branches with `/` character
body:
The terminal suggest feature was not properly normalizing path separators for git branch names containing `/` characters on Windows. While `git checkout tyriar/branch` worked correctly, `git branch -D tyriar/branch` did not normalize the `/` to `\` for proper filtering and completion.

## Problem

Git branch completions came from extensions with `documentation: "Branch"` but without an explicit completion item `kind`. This meant they were excluded from the path separator normalization logic that only applied to directories and files. As a result:

- ✅ `git checkout tyriar/` - worked (directories included in normalization)
- ❌ `git branch -D tyriar/` - broken (branches excluded from normalization)

![Issue demonstration](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8652333d-bcca-4b13-a4ce-1c600d383125)

## Solution

Added proper branch completion support by:

1. **Added `Branch` completion item kind** to `TerminalCompletionItemKind` enum
2. **Enhanced completion service** to automatically detect and set `Branch` kind for completions with `documentation: "Branch"`
3. **Updated path normalization logic** to include branches alongside directories and files
4. **Removed legacy hack** that relied on string-based documentation matching

## Implementation Details

The fix works by:
- Extensions provide branch completions with `documentation: "Branch"`
- Completion service post-processes these to set `kind: TerminalCompletionItemKind.Branch`
- Suggest addon now includes branches in `_isFilteringDirectoriesOrBranches` check
- Completion items normalize branch paths with `/` characters on Windows
- `normalizePathSeparator()` function handles branch filtering correctly

## Testing

Added comprehensive tests covering:
- Branch completion kind detection and assignment
- Path separator normalization on Windows vs other platforms
- Integration with existing git branch priority sorting

The solution ensures consistent behavior across all git commands that reference branch names containing path separators.

Fixes #262314.

title: Copilot Chat checkpoint restore intermittently fails - data loss risk
body:
- **Copilot Chat Extension Version**: 0.30.1
- **VS Code Version**: 1.103.1 (user setup)
- **OS Version**: Windows 11
- **Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode)**: Agent mode - checkpoint restore functionality
- **Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet)**: Claude Sonnet 4
- **Logs**: Not available - intermittent issue that occurred previously. Will enable trace logging if issue reproduces.

## Problem Description
Copilot Chat checkpoint restore functionality works inconsistently in agent mode. Sometimes restore succeeds normally, but sometimes fails completely with no error message or recovery option, creating significant data loss risk.

## Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start extended Copilot Chat session in agent mode using Claude Sonnet 4
2. Make changes across multiple files/folders through chat conversation
3. Continue making additional modifications with Copilot
4. Attempt to restore to an earlier checkpoint
5. **Result is inconsistent**: Sometimes works perfectly, sometimes fails completely

## Expected Behavior
Checkpoint restore should work reliably every time, allowing users to safely revert to previous states.

## Actual Behavior
- **Sometimes**: Restore works as expected
- **Sometimes**: Complete failure with no error message or indication of what went wrong
- When restore fails, there's no fallback mechanism
- Risk of losing significant work (I was saved only by file history + git staged changes)
- No visible error logs or diagnostics when failure occurs

## Additional Context
- Issue appears more frequent with longer chat sessions involving multiple files/folders
- No consistent pattern identified for when failures occur
- Failure is silent - no error messages displayed to user

## Suggested Technical Improvement
Consider implementing checkpoint storage using a separate local git branch mechanism. This would provide:
- More reliable restore functionality using proven version control methods
- Better change tracking and history
- Familiar git-based workflow that developers already understand

title: Terminal tool: Use hardcoded command list for telemetry reporting
body:
This implementation replaces the configurable command reporting system with a hardcoded allow list for terminal tool telemetry, addressing privacy and maintainability concerns.

## Changes Made

### Hardcoded Command List
- Replaced the `chat.tools.terminal.commandReportingAllowList` configuration setting with a static list of common development commands
- Commands include: git, npm, yarn, docker, kubectl, cargo, dotnet, mvn, gradle, pip, python, node, java, go, make, cmake
- List is maintained directly in the code near the telemetry implementation

### Separate Command Telemetry
- Changed from adding command fields to existing auto-approval telemetry to sending dedicated telemetry events
- Each command matching the allow list now generates a separate `toolUse.runInTerminal.command` event
- This approach provides better granularity and avoids skewing data by only reporting the first command

### Simplified Implementation
- Removed all command reporting configuration logic from `CommandLineAutoApprover`
- Command reporting is now always enabled for commands in the hardcoded list
- Global telemetry settings control whether events are actually sent

### Example Behavior

```bash
# Multiple commands in one execution
git status && npm install && echo "done"
```

With this change:
- Auto-approval telemetry: 1 event with overall approval status
- Command telemetry: 2 separate events (git and npm, echo is not in allow list)
- Better data granularity and no configuration required

## Privacy & Security

- Only pre-approved development commands are reported
- No sensitive arguments or output included
- No user configuration required - consistent behavior across all installations
- Users retain control via global telemetry settings

Fixes #262310.

title: Hide secondary sidebar by default in small windows (width < 1000px)
body:
Fixes #259852

This PR implements automatic hiding of the secondary sidebar (auxiliary bar) in small windows to improve the user experience on smaller screens and prevent cramped UI layouts.

## Changes

**Core Logic (`src/vs/workbench/browser/layout.ts`)**
- Added `AUXILIARY_BAR_SMALL_WINDOW_THRESHOLD = 1000` constant to define the minimum window width
- Modified the auxiliary bar default visibility logic to hide the sidebar when:
  - The user hasn't explicitly configured the `workbench.secondarySideBar.defaultVisibility` setting
  - AND the window width is less than 1000px

**Configuration Documentation (`src/vs/workbench/browser/workbench.contribution.ts`)**
- Updated the description of `workbench.secondarySideBar.defaultVisibility` to inform users about the small window behavior

**Testing (`src/vs/workbench/test/browser/auxiliaryBarSmallWindow.test.ts`)**
- Added unit tests to verify the window size logic works correctly

## Behavior

The implementation ensures that:

1. **Small windows (< 1000px)**: Secondary sidebar is hidden by default to preserve screen space
2. **Large windows (≥ 1000px)**: Existing behavior is preserved - sidebar visibility follows the configured setting
3. **User preferences are always respected**: If a user explicitly configures the sidebar visibility, their choice takes precedence regardless of window size

## Example Scenarios

```typescript
// Small window (800px), no user configuration
// Result: Secondary sidebar is hidden to save space

// Large window (1200px), no user configuration  
// Result: Secondary sidebar follows default visibility setting

// Small window (800px), user set visibility to "visible"
// Result: Secondary sidebar is shown (user preference respected)
```

This change addresses the cramped UI issue reported in smaller VS Code windows while maintaining full backward compatibility and respecting user customizations.

title: Copilot Chat adds undeletable Chat-edits in Chat List
body: Since about a week, every time I perform a chat edit in Copilot Chat, a new "New Chat (current)" entry appears in the "Show Chats" dropdown. These entries do not have an "X" to delete them. If I select one of these entries, the dropdown becomes unusable (it cannot be opened). After restarting VS Code, these entries disappear and the dropdown works again. Also, after disabling all extensions (except GitHub Copilot and GitHub Copilot Chat), the issue still exists. **Steps to Reproduce:** 1. Start a new chat in Copilot Chat 2. Perform a chat edit 3. Open the "Show Chats" dropdown 4. Observe multiple "New Chat (current)" entries without delete option **General info**: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.350.0 - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: Windows 11 Pro - Feature: ask mode - Selected model: GPT 4.1 - Logs: Nothing **Additional Info:** - I regularly delete chats, but the issue persists. - Setting `chat.edits2.enabled` is false. - No other chat-related extensions installed. - VS Code and Copilot Chat are up to date. **Screenshot:** (The dropdown on top looks like this when I perform the chat edits from the Copilot Chat right) (A “New Chat (current)” selected, with no message, and cannot be exited ) (After a restart, everything looks good again) **Expected Behavior:** Only one "New Chat" entry should appear per session, and all should be deletable. The dropdown should remain functional. **Actual Behavior:** Multiple undeletable "New Chat (current)" entries appear, and the dropdown breaks after selecting one.

title: Bug: Intermittent "Response contained no choices" error when using Gemini Pro API key
body:
Type: Bug ### Type Bug Report ### Description When GitHub Copilot is configured to use an external model via an API key (specifically Google's Gemini Pro), it frequently fails to return a response. The issue is intermittent but occurs most of the time. The chat panel displays one of two errors: 1. `Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Reason: Response contained no choices.` 2. `Sorry, no response was returned.` This suggests a potential problem in how Copilot handles the API response from externally configured models like Gemini. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Configure the GitHub Copilot extension to use a valid API key for the `Gemini Pro` model. 2. Open the Copilot Chat view. 3. Ask a simple question (e.g., "What is recursion?"). 4. Observe the error response. You may need to try a few times, as the issue is intermittent. ### Expected Behavior Copilot should consistently connect to the Gemini Pro endpoint, process the request, and stream back a valid response in the chat panel. ### Actual Behavior The request fails most of the time, returning an error message. The `Request id` changes with each attempt. **Error Message 1:** > Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: d909aa13-bf75-411b-a376-6ccd938fa403 > Reason: Response contained no choices. **Error Message 2:** > Sorry, no response was returned. **Relevant Console Output:** The console shows both successful and what appear to be failed requests.
